titleStmt.title: Variants of 1st person singular communis pronoun
titleStmt.author: Johanna Doppelbauer

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for the 1st person singular communis pronoun.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Rosenhouse (1984: 17) notes similar ani and āni forms of this pronoun for the north Israeli Bedouin

Rosenhouse (1984: 17) notes similar ani and āni forms of this pronoun for the north Israeli Bedouin
Cantineau's data (1937) also notes a diphthongized "anei"
Middle age speakers tend to alternate between ʔani and ʔana while old speakers use only ʔani and young speakers tend to use ʔana almost exclusively.
Middle age speakers tend to alternate between ʔani and ʔana while old speakers use only ʔani and young speakers tend to use ʔana almost exclusively.
vestigial variant ʔani
rare instances of aná
only one occurrence was found in texts, not in description
ʔāna only in the Hijazi group of the tribe
Belong to ʕAneze confederation
location belongs to group IIIa
dightongue of final vowel ʔānei according to Cantineau 1937
location belongs to group IIIb
belong to ʕAneze confederation
Deduced from examples
āna is also recorded but used less
āna is also recorded but used less
Among male informants, one hears irregularly the form 'ani.
ani is the 1st person feminine form used mainly by women
The oldest interviewed woman uses the Tihama-typical realisation "áni". A very rare but present phenomenon is the reduction of anā to nā.
The Brak and Shéké tribes use the variant ínä, while the Megarha use né.
It occurs both as anā and ānā.
The Zentan are known for their high number of variations. ne, ānä and ānāyä are also used.
Deduced from examples
The stress is on the second syllable.
the form ina is also used
the form ina is also used
